title: Cross River Bank Hires Crypto Compliance Chief From Robinhood; Benjamin Melnicki joins New Jersey-based bank catering to fintechs after spending a few months at Robinhood
text:
A spokeswoman for Cross River Bank confirmed his appointment and declined to comment further. A spokeswoman for Robinhood declined to comment.

The appointment comes as Cross River Bank, which is backed by some of Silicon Valley's top venture-capital firms, looks to make cryptocurrency a bigger part of its business.

The community bank, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J., and has two branches, one in nearby Teaneck and another in Brooklyn, N.Y., uses its position as a chartered and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.-member bank to help fintech firms do things that are tougher for nonbank firms under U.S. rules. That includes originating loans in any state and moving funds over the banking system's rails on behalf of its partners or customers.

Cross River Bank, which also offers commercial and personal banking services, has been growing rapidly. The bank said it hired more than 225 people in 2021 and its workforce has grown eightfold since 2017.

Before joining Robinhood, Mr. Melnicki was the chief compliance officer of digital-currency asset-management firm Grayscale Investments LLC for about nine months, according to his LinkedIn profile. Before Grayscale, he worked as regulatory counsel at cryptocurrency startup Ripple Labs Inc. and Blockchain.com, a provider of cryptocurrency services to retail and institutional clients, with each position lasting about a year. Earlier, he was director of swap-dealer compliance at Bank of America Corp.

Mr. Melnicki's move comes as the cryptocurrency industry faces turmoil. Prices of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies have been plummeting as interest rates rise and investors have continued to unload assets viewed as risky, including cryptocurrencies. Crypto exchange company Coinbase Global Inc. said it would cut almost a fifth of its staff. Crypto lender Celsius Network LLC hired restructuring attorneys to help handle its mounting financial problems after freezing user accounts.

Robinhood, meanwhile, said in April that it was laying off 9% of its full-time workers and cutting back on duplicate roles it added when the investment platform was growing rapidly beginning in 2020.
